subject: Art
title: The Color Wheel
description: The foundational tool that organizes colors by their relationships.

hook.text: In 1666, Isaac Newton bent a beam of sunlight through a prism, saw the spectrum, and wrapped it into a circle. The color wheel was born â€” and artists have used it ever since.

buildup.text: Primary colors: red, yellow, blue â€” they can't be mixed from other colors. Secondary colors: orange, green, violet â€” made by mixing two primaries. Tertiary colors: red-orange, yellow-green, etc. â€” mixing a primary with an adjacent secondary.

discovery.text: The wheel shows relationships: colors opposite each other are complementary (high contrast). Colors next to each other are analogous (harmonious). These relationships are the basis of all color schemes.

twist.text: There are actually different color wheels. The traditional RYB wheel is for painters. The RGB wheel is for screens. The CMY wheel is for printing. Each has different primaries for different media.

climax.text: Memorize the 12-color wheel: 3 primaries, 3 secondaries, 6 tertiaries. It's your roadmap for every color decision you'll ever make.

punchline.text: The color wheel isn't just a diagram. It's the GPS of color.
